description: From Latin polyhistor (“very learned”), from Hellenistic Ancient Greek πολυΐστωρ (poluḯstōr, “greatly learned”).

entries.meaning: Someone gifted or learned to a great extent or in multiple disciplines; a great scholar. [from 16th c.]
examples: A hired diplomat in Edirne and to the Porte in Constantinople, a military commander in the Austro-Turkish wars, a polyhistor and a learned man.
